content:
@__hot_town__ in <#1460237271658926144> at <t:1768218095:R>:
>>> Hey Claude Code people,

I'm Vince, Dev Rel for Wasp.sh (fullstack React/Node/Prisma framework with batteries-included), and I'm working hard on an official Wasp plugin for Claude Code.

We want to import some Wasp rules/best practices into Claude's memory after the user installs the plugin and uses it within a Wasp project. Is there any way to package rules or a CLAUDE.md from within the plugin so that it automatically gets added to memory after install?

At the moment, I have a `general-wasp-knowledge.md` doc and a `/wasp:init` slash command that comes with the plugin. The idea is to use the `SessionStart` hook to alert the user to run this command, which just adds an import line to the `general-wasp-knowledge.md` doc in their CLAUDE.md file:
```md
  ‚éø  SessionStart:startup says:
    
     IMPORTANT! The Wasp plugin hasn't been initialized for the current project.
     Run /wasp:init to get the plugin's full functionality -- or reply "opt out" to never see this message again. 
```

I'm wondering if this is a bad practice, or if there's a more efficient way to achieve this result?

content:
I've got a question about prompt engineering. In React (front-end development), you have components which are similar to HTML tags e.g. `<MyComponent>`. 

If I was to write the following in CC: `> I am working with the <Cell> component`

Is there risk that the left and right angled brackets somehow get misinterpreted and not seen as a React component, or lead to bloat while it tries to figure out what the brackets are? Should this be in quotes e.g. `"<Cell>"`?

content: First, please do not tag staff here. They aren't support. Unfortunately, none of the staff or mods here have access to account or billing information and we can't assist with those issues. If you have submitted the ban appeal form as found in <#1114301961831981107> then the Trust & Safety team will respond. It can take some time depending on the level of appeals in the queue. If you don't hear back you can also try emailing support@mail.anthropic.com.

content:
Call me crazy, but I thought the whole point of a status page was to have it display issues automatically, like, every company I've worked for, their status page displayed stats on status based on monitoring scripts and such, so even if everyone was asleep, the page showed an issue, just no this is being addressed message

But Anthropics feels like it's a static html page with some basic JavaScript to show green, until some tech updates it to show red, after people have complained.

It is the most useless status page I have ever seen for any company.

author: secretary_birb#0

content: In my experience, the Claude models are not very good at the 'creative' part, a tradeoff for being tuned to reduce hallucinations, I suspect. For example, ask it to introduce a male character and you've got a very high chance it will name that character "Marcus Chen". It can write okay prose, but actually coming up with creative elements to write about will just produce extremely generic slop that converges around cliches
author: jarlyk#0

content: To be clear, the above isn't a bad thing for a coding model (you don't want your coding models to be overly creative; you want them to use good solutions and being similar to other solutions is a good thing, on the whole.)  Just means that Claude's coding focus makes it a bit limited in creative areas.

author: zana3268#0

content: Claude follows pretty closely to whatever path you've carved out for it.  It can be extremely loquacious if you ask it to be or if you demonstrate that you'd like it to be, but lacking any specific guidance, it'll default to an inoffensive median personality. In terms of hallucinations, the term is a little vaguely defined, but, yes, it can get worse with larger contexts. In the specific context of creative writing, the tricky thing is that controlled hallucination is actually often what you want; coming up with plausibly fitting concepts that aren't grounded in any sort of external facts, but fit overall patterns for the narrative you're trying to tell. Claude leans more toward the less creative side, I believe largely because it's so optimized for coding. Most models are being tuned this way currently.

author: doctorrewards#0

content:
I want to be honest with you,  OPUS is largly an introspection qualia engine, you should leverage it for planning and research and then delegate all the work to Sonnets (I call them Sonics lol).    the "Best" you will get is if you implement the following process.

-----
1. OPUS (Design, Delegate prompts (via MD or an A2A infrastucture), sequentual or parallel decision up to OPUS.
2. Sonnet agent per prompt build the entire product and unit test.
3. OPUS (having context of the design and delegation)  now Validates the work of Sonnets, and catches the dropped balls.
4. Switch overseer (from OPUS to Sonnet) and leverage the entire design, delegation and fixes session history into generating all your documentation, and development logs.
-----

This approach allows you to leverage OPUS to churn out a full production-grade product in one go. if you don't use persistent memory like me, it's a good idea to output your designs into MD files and request illustrations (if the product is frontend UX) and iterate over MD files, thus you have more control over the data iteration un-muddied from the rest of the conversation).


üôÇ I hope that helps pal!  happy to help if you have deeper questions on how OPUS works!
